There's no particularly good reason for shareholders to deny the pushy investor  whose hedge fund Trian Partners owns 1.5 percent of the $235 billion diapers-to-shampoo conglomerate  a seat at the table. column4: Breakingviews - Cox: P&G counting on an investor electoral college
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters Breakingviews) - Procter & Gamble is counting on a variation of America's electoral arithmetic as its best hope for keeping Nelson Peltz off the board of directors. There's no particularly good reason for shareholders to deny the pushy investor  whose hedge fund Trian Partners owns 1.5 percent of the $235 billion diapers-to-shampoo conglomerate  a seat at the table. Yet as at the ballot box  a combination of voter apathy and arcane rules is likely to leave three investors holdi
